title: Go-To Cabbage Kimchi
ingredients: - 17 grams (2 tablespoons) Diamond Crystal kosher salt
- 8 ounces yellow or white onion (1 medium), roughly chopped
- 1½ ounces ginger (4-inch knob), scrubbed and roughly sliced against the grain
- ½ ounce garlic cloves (5 medium), peeled
- 8½ ounces gochugaru (Korean chili flakes), about 2 cups
- 6 tablespoons homemade Mushroom Seasoning Powder or 2 ounces store-bought (½ cup)
- 3 ounces scallions (about 6), trimmed and chopped into 1-inch pieces
directions: 1. Remove any bruised leaves from the cabbage and trim any brown spots, but leave the visible core intact. Halve the cabbage through the core, then make three 1-inch-deep slits in the bottom of the core of each half.
2. Tear each half into quarters lengthwise by hand. Place the cabbage in a large bowl.
3. Add the salt in stages, rubbing it between the leaves and onto the cabbage. Let sit for about 4 hours, flipping every 30 minutes, until wilted and releasing liquid.
4. Drain well and return the cabbage to the bowl.
5. In a small saucepan, whisk the rice flour and 2 cups water over high heat until boiling. Add the sugar, stir, and transfer to a heatproof bowl to cool.
6. Once cooled, blend the rice mixture with onion, ginger, and garlic until smooth. Transfer to a mixing bowl.
7. Add gochugaru, mushroom seasoning, sambal, vinegar, scallions, and ¼ cup water. Stir well.
8. Use gloved hands or a spoon to spread a thin layer of the chili mixture between each cabbage leaf.
9. Transfer the cabbage to a wide-mouth 2-quart glass jar and pour in any remaining chili mixture.
10. Press down with a spoon so the liquid rises to (or nearly) cover the vegetables.
11. Cover with plastic wrap pressed to the surface, add a small weight, and seal with a lid.
12. Let ferment at room temperature for 3 to 5 days, burping after 3 days, until bubbles form and it sours slightly.
13. Once fermented to your liking, store in the fridge for up to 6 weeks.
